newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine labor talks agenda to be set Thursday.
newsitem.headline: Argentine labor talks agenda to be set Thursday.

text.p: Argentine government officials, trade union leaders and businessmen will meet at 1700 local/2000 GMT this Thursday to draw up an agenda for negotiations on labor reforms, local news agencies reported.
The meeting was scheduled for Wednesday but postponed without further explanation.
Cabinet Strategic Secretary Alberto Abad said Wednesday there were no restrictions on the three-way negotiations on labor reforms that will start up in February.
But he said the agenda would be short in order for the talks to be effective.
"Nobody imposes debate on any problems because we want an agenda agreed by consensus," Abad said.

"There are no preconceived ideas about what can or can't be debated," he said. "What is clear is that the government's main policies will be upheld, and what we will do is debate aspects that can be refocused or revitalized...and allow all sides to be satisfied."
The CGT labor federation has warned that workers would go back on the warparth with strikes and marches if the labor reform negotiations failed.
It has staged two strikes since September against moves to make employment conditions more flexible, curtail union control over health care plans and reduce their role in collective wage bargaining.
Three labor reform decrees signed by President Carlos Menem in December have been overturned by the courts, while the remaining reform bills await debate in in Congress.
